article_title: Perry and Cruz test messages for possible presidential bids
article_text: To continue reading this story, you will need to be a digital subscriber to HoustonChronicle.com.

article_metadata.description: FORT WORTH - Gov. Rick Perry urged rebellion and U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz counted conservative victories as the potential 2016 presidential contenders courted grassroots activists Friday before heading to the key early voting state of Iowa.  [...] faced with another power-hungry oppressive ruler in a faraway place, it's time for us to start a little rebellion, said Perry, who touted a new political action committee he has set up as a weapon in the war for the U.S. Senate in November.  Perry showcases his long experience as governor, highlighting the state's economic successes; urges a lighter hand by the federal government in most areas; and bemoans a federal border policy that boosted his national profile as he stepped into breach by activating the National Guard.  Cruz is a fresher face with a high profile who has solidified support among his party's movement conservatives, angering the GOP establishment and thwarting efforts on health care and border initiatives he found too conciliatory to the left.  "With the combination of the fair and this (summit) event, you've got Iowa crawling with prospective Republican presidential candidates," said political science professor Dennis Goldford of Drake University in Des Moines.  Perry "doesn't channel rage the way Cruz does," Goldford said, calling that characteristic of the senator one that is positive for tea-party voters but negative for a general election and the "Chamber of Commerce wing of the GOP."
article_metadata.author.name: By Peggy Fikac
